justification: "Reinforcement learning behavior can be fit with computational models that mathematically formalize distinct learning parameters to characterize different components of the decision-making process."
"When tasked with making go or no-go responses, age-related differences in learning are best captured by changes in action initiation (tendency to press a button)…"
The same go/no-go study noted that "sensitivity to punishment… increases with age," indicating this construct was quantified within the go/no-go paradigm.
"Emerging computational evidence using reinforcement learning models suggests that adolescents are also more sensitive to 'likes' than adults, both on social media and in lab experiments."

"When presented with two choice options, children and adolescents are more likely to rely on learning from negative feedback than adults, who tend to rely on positive feedback when updating their decisions."
